title: Unnamed Project - Finish or Discard?
content:
Hi All,

Like many first-time posters, I'm not entirely new to the site, having lurked in the shadows for a while.

I won't give you a full biography now, but will tell you that I've developed an unhealthy interest in type design since being forced to reinvent myself due to illness. My background is technology sales, not design, so my efforts have tended towards the simple. Which is why I find myself in need of some opinions about my latest font.

Let me try to set the scene.

Imagine walking a well-known street. Every so often, you check out an unknown side street , but you don't walk too far down it, because your instincts are to stick with what you are familiar with. However, on one occasion, you find yourself in one of these side streets by accident and walk a bit further down it. You're not comfortable - you keep turning, about to retrace your steps, but an inner voice tells you to keep exploring this strange street.

You get to a point where you have to make a decision: return or keep going? This is where I am with this design.

I was editing the internal contour of an 'O' in a geometric sans I'd been drawing when I accidentally changed a smooth node to a corner node. There was something about this 'pinched' contour I liked, even though I didn't (and still don't) understand why, and I ended up creating a set of lower case glyphs based on this idea. I've created a TTF file and you can see the output in the linked PDF below.

[http://freepdfhosting.com/e290ad9e0c.pdf](http://web.archive.org/web/20150404082217/http:/freepdfhosting.com/e290ad9e0c.pdf "http://freepdfhosting.com/e290ad9e0c.pdf")

I'm incredibly conflicted about what I have and have held back on designing the upper case glyphs until I can resolve the way I feel about it. Sometimes I look at individual letterforms and hate them; sometimes, I look at the same letterforms and love their quirkiness. The only time I consistently like what I have so far is when I see a segment of body text at around 36pt and it's for this reason I'm asking for the community's view.

Does this design have promise (and, if so, any thoughts about refining the characters I have) or, should I turn back to my well-known street?

Thanks in advance, Steve
author: Steve Gardner

comments.content:
I, for one, find it interesting, and worth pursuing.  
Keep in mind, though, that it’s not an uncharted road: [http://typophile.com/node/41687](http://web.archive.org/web/20150404082217/http:/typophile.com/node/41687 "http://typophile.com/node/41687")  
 [http://typography.net/fontfamilies/view/39](http://web.archive.org/web/20150404082217/http:/typography.net/fontfamilies/view/39 "http://typography.net/fontfamilies/view/39")

Hi riccard0 and thanks for your feedback.

If I made it sound as though I'd stumbled upon some hitherto unknown design feature, I apologise. I only intended to say that the style was one I'd not experimented with before and that I am unsure of my execution.

What I meant was just that, if you think you need it, you could look at how others have tackled the style.  
It’s always a tradeoff between avoiding reinventing the wheel regarding what works and what don’t,\* and the risk of being influenced too much by others’ arbitrary aesthetic decisions.

\* Which also depends on the underlying design decisions you make: most of the typefaces in the style are calligraphic in structure, while something like Fenland is not.  
In any case, the M-Formula stands as a method to evaluate the result: [http://typophile.com/node/18643](http://web.archive.org/web/20150404082217/http:/typophile.com/node/18643 "http://typophile.com/node/18643")

And I think this is at the heart of my issue: this font did not come about because of a carefully thought through set of design decisions, but more as a "hmmm... that might be interesting - I'll run with it and see where it leads me" sort of thing! :)

Thanks for the links - I take a good look before deciding whether to develop this font further. Meantime, I've addressed a couple of minor issues I found and also added terminals to the /a/, /c/, /s/ and /z/, which I think I prefer.

[http://freepdfhosting.com/473450fd3e.pdf](http://web.archive.org/web/20150404082217/http:/freepdfhosting.com/473450fd3e.pdf "http://freepdfhosting.com/473450fd3e.pdf")

I would continue working on this your second already pdf looks nicer - and I like the squarish o counter. Looking at the letters in a half-focused way the o's seemed to have a small pinch in the upper left corner of the counter. You can experiment with such a design idea, exaggerate it perhaps make a half or complete cut there, and start the letter as if it were made with a calligraphic rounded brush. Or end the stroke with a little flourish? Whatever you do carry on the new style to the other letters in a uniform way- now the the b for example looks too sedate and incongruent next to the o.

Steve, life is funny, isn't it.

Although you arrived at the peculiar countershape via a happy accident, to me the most notable thing is that it looks like a reflection of the traditional, calligraphic way of making letterforms via a broad-nib pen. So I think the main decision you need to first take is whether to revert to that construction and have a much easier time completing a font that presumably you and certainly many others would find attractive, or to instead try to avoid that reference and make something truly fresh, which however would be a greater challenge.

As for the caps, that's actually another tricky fork in the road. You can make caps that essentially look like a separate alphabet (the conventional way) or you can try to innovate and make caps that look like they belong with the lowercase (for which you might look to uncial).

hhp

Vladimir and hrant - thank you both for sharing your thoughts.

I have been experimenting this evening - the latest version is at:

[http://freepdfhosting.com/146fbf183e.pdf](http://web.archive.org/web/20150404082217/http:/freepdfhosting.com/146fbf183e.pdf "http://freepdfhosting.com/146fbf183e.pdf")

Vladimir - I pulled the outer contour in a little on the /o/ and changed the counter in the /b/, /d/, /p/ and /q/ as you suggested. I've also edited a number of other letters to try to get some design consistency, but I can't help feeling as if I'm reverse-engineering a design philosophy instead of being led by one. Thoughts?

hrant - I will expand upon the broad-nib pen characteristics, but I don't want to lose too much of the ruggedness. I've grown to really enjoy the unpredictable shapes and quirky features, and I don't want to sacrifice them. If that means the font ends up with a bit of an identity crisis, I'll chalk it up to experience and move on.

I think I will attempt the caps. The /C/, /O/ and /S/ draw themselves and I like your idea of looking to uncial for inspiration.

Cheers, Steve
Give this much more letterspace (and a narrower wordspace) and it will help you make judgements about where to go with it.

A couple of observations:  
|x| looks a bit dark, and personally I’m not sold to the curve on the top right terminal. You could lighten the centre and/or increase the contrast of the strokes.  
|g|’s bottom bowl doesn’t seem to work well, it ends up too conventional. Have you considered an open tail?

@ I've also edited a number of other letters to try to get some design consistency  
Good it seems to be working

@but I can't help feeling as if I'm reverse-engineering a design philosophy instead of being led by one.

I am really no expert in Latin fonts, and had to struggle for years with my own; there may well be no one ideal way of approaching this sort of work - be pragmatic, adjust what you have done, what you imagine it should be, and - as happened with you - by trial and error. Keep on polishing this and that and see where that alley takes you!

Here's a link to the latest version.

[http://freepdfhosting.com/036ca0ba41.pdf](http://web.archive.org/web/20150404082217/http:/freepdfhosting.com/036ca0ba41.pdf "http://freepdfhosting.com/036ca0ba41.pdf")

Changes include:

- new /g/ with open bowl  
- removal of curves from top right of /v/, /w/, /x/ and /y/ - replaced with subtle kinks to break stroke uniformity  
- minor adjustment to /x/ weight (needs further adjustment?)  
- minor redraw of /c/, /e/ and /s/ for balance  
- more letterspace

I think this 'open' style of /g/ works better, but I'm far from convinced I have it right yet. I'd really appreciate any ideas about this, as well as any other ideas you might have for the other letters.

Cheers, Steve

Letters with diagonals: better, especially |v|. Some could use a bit more lightening, |x| in particular.  
You could want to revise |z| too.  
I think what doesn’t work in |g| is that the bottom right stroke is too weak to support the “pinch”, you could look at the top of |a|’s bowl for comparison.  
Lastly, I would give a second look to |e|’s bottom stroke.

riccardo - I've widened the stroke at the 'pinch' in the /g/ and it does look a great deal better. Thanks!

I've also lightened the /w/, /x/ and /z/ a touch. I haven't been too aggressive with this, because I don't want to go too much the other way - do you think they're better now?

Finally, for now, could you tell me a bit more about what you don't like about the bottom stroke of the /e/? Do you think it should be 'pinched' at the 7 o'clock position, for example? It is almost identical (literally to within a tiny fraction of 1%) to the lower half of the /c/ - presumably, the /c/ trouble you in the same way the /e/ does?

[http://freepdfhosting.com/4d39ded5ae.pdf](http://web.archive.org/web/20150404082217/http:/freepdfhosting.com/4d39ded5ae.pdf "http://freepdfhosting.com/4d39ded5ae.pdf")

**EDIT TO ADD:**

I've made a change in anticipation of your agreeing to the idea of 'pinching the /e/ (and /c/) at the 7 o'clock position.

[http://freepdfhosting.com/aeba27e1c1.pdf](http://web.archive.org/web/20150404082217/http:/freepdfhosting.com/aeba27e1c1.pdf "http://freepdfhosting.com/aeba27e1c1.pdf")

I think they are all improvements.  
As for |e|, and |c|, while ⅔ of the curve may be the same, |c|’s terminal and |e|’s bowl counterbalance it differently, and |e| could look a bit unbalanced. Also, not counting the ascender/descender stems, it’s the longest continuous “thick” stroke. I don’t think a pinch would work, but maybe a little tapering.

Ok, I have to step away for a while now, but I'll take another look at this later this evening.

Thanks for all your input - really appreciate it.

Revised /e/ and stroke weight adjustment to shoulders of /h, /m/, /n/ and /u/.

[http://freepdfhosting.com/f3280183c2.pdf](http://web.archive.org/web/20150404082217/http:/freepdfhosting.com/f3280183c2.pdf "http://freepdfhosting.com/f3280183c2.pdf")

Looks promising!

The thinning of the /a at the top right feels unnatural to me; it goes against pen logic.

I would rotate the tittles clockwise a bit.

Have you considered a round foot for /t?

Some of the abrupt endings (such as at the top of /b, tail of /z) and rectangular serifs and crossbars (/a, /f, /t, /z) strike me as off-character compared to the more organic shapes that prevail in the other characters. Consider adding some flaring to those.

There is no such thing as "pen logic" in type beyond the logic of nostalgia.

hhp

@Catharsis - thanks for your suggestions.

I've redrawn the /a/ so that it is consistent with the rest of the font. Having 'shaved' so much weight off of this font in an attempt to apply more calligraphic principles, it's nice to be able to put a bit of weight back in!

I also rotated the tittles (and, in the case of the /j/, repositioned it). The latest version is at:  
 [http://freepdfhosting.com/d5e47c0c2d.pdf](http://web.archive.org/web/20150404082217/http:/freepdfhosting.com/d5e47c0c2d.pdf "http://freepdfhosting.com/d5e47c0c2d.pdf")

The /t/ has been a recurring issue for me. The very first draft of the font, which preceded the first upload here, had a more conventional round foot, but I didn't like it. I have actually tried a couple more times to introduce it since discussing the font here, but I always end up preferring the straighter style. Do you think this font is desperately crying out for a rounded /t/?

As for the stroke endings, I've experimented a little here as well. Again, going back to my first 'pre-Typophile' version, the stroke endings you mentioned terminated with a curl, similar to the right sides of the /v/, /w/, /x/ and /y/ found in earlier versions (such as [http://freepdfhosting.com/e290ad9e0c.pdf](http://web.archive.org/web/20150404082217/http:/freepdfhosting.com/e290ad9e0c.pdf "http://freepdfhosting.com/e290ad9e0c.pdf")). They've since been 'iterated' out, but do you think the font would now work better if I reintroduced them, or some variation on that theme?

I have to say that really like the asymmetrical crossbars and the serifs, which use the same shape. That doesn't mean to say I opposed to change and I'll certainly experiment with other ideas.

@hrant - you said earlier in this thread that you thought "_...the main decision [I] need to first take is whether to revert to [a calligraphic] construction..._". I think you were right and, though my interpretation might be a little loose, the /a/ does work better without that 'pinch'.

As a rapid follow-up, I've edited the top vertical stoke terminals to match the /n/ and /m/.

[http://freepdfhosting.com/793bd802d0.pdf](http://web.archive.org/web/20150404082217/http:/freepdfhosting.com/793bd802d0.pdf "http://freepdfhosting.com/793bd802d0.pdf")

Personally, I prefer the straighter strokes to this particular alternative, but would be interested to have the community's view.

A version reverting to straight terminals, but with rounded /t/.

[http://freepdfhosting.com/01700999d5.pdf](http://web.archive.org/web/20150404082217/http:/freepdfhosting.com/01700999d5.pdf "http://freepdfhosting.com/01700999d5.pdf")

Thoughts as to best combination from my last three posts?

Sorry to flood the updates, but I wanted to add this to the mix.

I've tried to address the abruptness Catharsis pointed out by pinching the vertical stems slightly in the middle and flaring them slightly at the ends. The difference is subtle, but it does give a softer effect.

Is this an improvement or should I look for another solution? Or, should I simply leave them rigid?

[http://freepdfhosting.com/5581b2e878.pdf](http://web.archive.org/web/20150404082217/http:/freepdfhosting.com/5581b2e878.pdf "http://freepdfhosting.com/5581b2e878.pdf")

I don't like the version with the /n-like tops on ascenders much.

I do like the slightly flaring stems on /i and /f, for example, but I'd make the flaring a little bit stronger on the ascenders and descenders. The stem on the /b also looks a bit unnatural to me, maybe it's that "pinch" you mentioned? Make sure the left and right edges of the stem work together well; I think that might involve making the bottom of the stem a bit wider into the bowl.

The tittles don't quite sit well yet to my eye.

The break in /z looks like a fracture. Maybe a curve would work better?

The /g has a wood-carved, choppy character that feels a bit out of place among the smoother other characters. Maybe you could smooth out some of the kinks and give the tail a bit more flow? I know it's a hard one to draw, but it also has the potential to be particularly noteworthy if done right. Maybe also allow the eye region of /g to have slightly lighter strokes than the /o, since they're so close to each other?

Just an idea: What would the font look like if there were no serifs on /a and /z, just some flaring?

Just make a super family! ;-)  
(I dig the asymmetric serifs)

I can see this working out both as a sans and as a serif. The merit of the serif version is currently a bit difficult to judge at the moment, though, since the spacing got messed up.

I see what you mean about the /g. I think there might be ways to reduce the number of kinks and still keep true to the style, but you'll have to see for yourself. (For instance, maybe if the neck were to join the tail in a corner rather than in a tight bend, that might tidy things up a bit?)

For the sans, I think your /a will do just fine without a serifed terminal.
+1 for the serifless |a|.

@Catharsis

Thanks for all your comments and suggestions. I really like the idea of changing the link of the /g/ from a bend to a corner - I think that will give it the flow you felt was absent without losing the character. I'm going to spend a bit of time working through this and all the other ideas we've discussed; hope to have a revision ready within the next 24 hours.
@riccard0 - would you advise removing the serif on the /c/ and /s/ also?

For |s|, I would say yes (lose the serif), it looks very closed with the serif (maybe also because it looks a bit narrow compared to other letters). I like the serif in |c|, but of course it need to be seen if it will feel out of place with the others.
Thanks for your thoughts. I'll have a revision sometime tomorrow.

Here's the latest version. It includes a large number of changes, ranging from the obvious to the almost imperceptible!

[http://freepdfhosting.com/59204157c2.pdf](http://web.archive.org/web/20150404082217/http:/freepdfhosting.com/59204157c2.pdf "http://freepdfhosting.com/59204157c2.pdf")

Changes include:

- removed serif from /a/ and /s/  
- added/redrawn terminal flares on all stems, ascenders and descenders (excluding /v/, /w/, /x/ and /y/)  
- smoothed the kink in the /z/ and flared the horizontal stokes  
- resized, reoriented and repositioned the tittles  
- redrawn /g/, including slight increase in counter to lighten stroke weight; right-shifted link; reshaped link; and a general smoothing out of the contours, especially in the loop

Latest version:

[http://freepdfhosting.com/82b32336c5.pdf](http://web.archive.org/web/20150404082217/http:/freepdfhosting.com/82b32336c5.pdf "http://freepdfhosting.com/82b32336c5.pdf")

In addition to the earlier changes (see post above), this version includes redrawn top of /a/ and adjustment to weight of /k/.
What does "gg" look like?
@eliason - email [steve@explogos.com](mailto:steve@explogos.com) and I'll send you the TTF

I've been working on the caps and have linked to three PDFs showing them in different contexts.

[http://freepdfhosting.com/766504ae02.pdf](http://web.archive.org/web/20150404082217/http:/freepdfhosting.com/766504ae02.pdf "http://freepdfhosting.com/766504ae02.pdf")

[http://freepdfhosting.com/9378bf3960.pdf](http://web.archive.org/web/20150404082217/http:/freepdfhosting.com/9378bf3960.pdf "http://freepdfhosting.com/9378bf3960.pdf")

[http://freepdfhosting.com/4d4f0c3fc6.pdf](http://web.archive.org/web/20150404082217/http:/freepdfhosting.com/4d4f0c3fc6.pdf "http://freepdfhosting.com/4d4f0c3fc6.pdf")

I haven't applied kerning yet and I am aware of a number of drawing issues (poorly executed curves, flares, etc) but wanted to get some feedback before taking the next step.

Do any characters appear too heavy or light? Does the relationship between the caps and lower case work, both in terms if size and weight? Any other thoughts?

Thanks in advance and have a great weekend!
Very handsome, all in all!

Thanks! And thanks for your earlier comments - not sure if the strokes end in quite the way you envisioned when you made the suggestion to review them, but they currently look much better than they did.

Since posting links to the caps, I have edited the baseline stroke endings of the /H/ and /M/, making them asymmetrical (not sure why I made the symmetrical in the first place, since none of the lower case characters have symmetrical stroke ends!). The change isn't enough to warrant a new link, but I'll update it once I fix some of the other issues.

Meantime, if you (or anyone) see any issue you think I should take a look at, I'd really appreciate your thoughts.

Maybe think of ways to enlarge the two smaller counters and/or reduce the one larger counter in the /M/.  
The other caps could probably stand to be a little darker, I think.  
The intersection of /Y/ is low--I don't see that off-center balance on any other letters.  
/X/ may be a bit too wide.

@eliason - thanks for your feedback.

I had already addressed the /M/. I thought it looked just a little too condensed, so widened it by around 4%. This allowed me to increase the counters without affecting the diagonal stroke weight.

Here's the revision:

[http://freepdfhosting.com/d3346442af.pdf](http://web.archive.org/web/20150404082217/http:/freepdfhosting.com/d3346442af.pdf "http://freepdfhosting.com/d3346442af.pdf")

I'll darken the caps a bit and address the /X/ width. I'll also the take a look at the /Y/ - I agree, something is wrong with the balance. I think this is because of the asymmetric stem flare. I'll see if shifting the weight a bit to the left works. I don't really want to remove the flare - that would be anomalous.

By the way... anyone have any ideas about a name for this font?

Here's my last update for tonight.

[http://freepdfhosting.com/1c27316707.pdf](http://web.archive.org/web/20150404082217/http:/freepdfhosting.com/1c27316707.pdf "http://freepdfhosting.com/1c27316707.pdf")

[http://freepdfhosting.com/73e67dc10b.pdf](http://web.archive.org/web/20150404082217/http:/freepdfhosting.com/73e67dc10b.pdf "http://freepdfhosting.com/73e67dc10b.pdf")

Changes include:

Wider /M/  
Narrower /X/  
Re-balanced /Y/  
Tail of /Q/ thickened at juncture  
Caps a touch darker - do they need to be even darker?  
Smoother outlines of several glyphs

Top left of /e strikes me as too thin...

Not sure if I like the corner of /b/q.

/Y is still a bit tilted at the foot.

I do like the execution of the extender terminals now.

Names: How about Gravensteiner?

@Catharsis

I think you're right about the /e/. It needs to be a bit darker at that pinch point. On review, I think I need the lighten the /g/ just a little bit in the same area.

The /b/ & /q/ corners were shaved to solve a weight issue I had at that juncture. The curve of the stroke naturally thickens at that point. With the /p/ and /d/, I could get away with thinning the stroke because the descender gave balance, but a thinner stroke on the /b/ looked wrong absent a descender. I also looked at simply flipping the /d/ to create a /b/ but, aside from seeming a lazy solution, it left the pinch points on the opposite side to where they should be. I hope that makes sense, as I don't have time right now to post an image.

Any ideas on an alternative solution?

I'm similarly stumped for a solution to my /Y/ problem. Virtually all stems flare asymmetrically. Single-stemmed glyphs flare to the left at the base; double-stemmed glyphs flare to the left on the left stem and to the right on the right stem. In the case of the /m/ - the only, but logical, exception - the middle stem flares both left and right.

I treated the /Y/ in the same way as, for example, the /f/ - a single flare to the left. But, because the /Y/ stem isn't long enough for the flare to even out, the original version had a horribly unbalanced look, which I tried to address by shifting the arms to the left. If your view is that this remains a problem, the only solution I can think of is to remove the flare altogether, since going the other way and creating a symmetrical flare makes the stem too dark.

Do you think a flare-less /Y/ would be acceptable as an illogical exception? Or, do you have any other ideas I could experiment with?

Thanks for the name suggestion. What is your thinking behind that name?
FWIW, the balance I was talking about on the /Y/ was top to bottom--I just meant you might want the join of the arms and stem higher.

A quick update:

[http://freepdfhosting.com/1dd1f48992.pdf](http://web.archive.org/web/20150404082217/http:/freepdfhosting.com/1dd1f48992.pdf "http://freepdfhosting.com/1dd1f48992.pdf")

- revision to /b/ and /q/ junctions  
- increased weight of /e/ at pinch point.  
- decreased weight of /g/ bowl at pinch points  
- changed tittles and introduced period and comma.

No change to the /Y/ at this point.

My two cents:  
|b| better, but I think you could go for something like |G|’s implied beard (jawline?).  
Not sure about the new tittle (maybe too square? too low? too parallel?). Perhaps you could try a diamond shape.\*  
Same for punctuation. Comma seems a bit clunky, could be rotated a bit anticlockwise.  
I agree with Craig about |Y|’s crotch being still a bit low.  
I also find |a|’s tail dark, and see a bit too much contrast between top and bottom of |A|’s stems.

\* [http://typophile.com/node/97738](http://web.archive.org/web/20150404082217/http:/typophile.com/node/97738 "http://typophile.com/node/97738")

Hi riccard0 and thanks, as always, for your thoughts.

I'll take another look at all the points you've mentioned a little later this evening. But, I did want to share this with you for now and get some feedback, if possible.

This is my first design for the tittle, period and comma.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150404082217im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Comma_4468.png)

I changed it because the relationship between the angles seemed to jar, particularly when brought together in a semicolon. Also, the tittle/period seemed to rigid, but it would be easy to soften the edges a little (and probably make the comma a little thinner).

Do you think these two (or, some variation of these two) work together ok?
